prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are mainly interested in detecting CO(2-1). The 1.875 GHz bandwidth will be used in dual polarization mode, with the CO(2-1) line placed in the lower sideband (LSB). We will also place the CS(5-4) line in the upper sideband (USB), in the event that this high-density line is strong enough to be detected in areas where the gas is more compact.

We require an angular resolution of 0.1 (corresponding to a physical scale of ~100 pc at z=0.061). This is sufficient to resolve individual large clouds, nuclear disks and structures around the nuclei for our two double nuclei systems.

In order to estimate the required sensitivities and integration times, we have used all existing CO mm-wave emission line and FIR/submm continuum data in the literature for each of our sources. Table 1 gives estimates of the total CO(2-1) emission line flux and the measured continuum fluxes for each target from the literature. We have made the conservative assumption that the total CO(2-1) emission is smoothly distributed within a nuclear region 2 arcsec in diameter. To estimate the required RMS sensitivity, we divided the estimated flux by the number of beams required to cover a 2 arcsec diameter with a pixel size of 0.1 arcsec (~300 beams) and assumed a channel width of 50 km/s. To reach a S/N of ~5, we will require an RMS sensitivity of ~480 uJy/synthesized beam and an integration time of 16 min on source. For more compact gas distributions, the S/N will of course be higher, but we would like to be able to detect extended faint structures such as high-velocity molecular winds, jets, plumes, etc., which may be present in the majority of our sources based on the most recent data from Herschel (Sturm et al. 2011). We will simultaneous get 1.3mm continuum which will be used to estimate dust masses. Given that continuum sensitivity expected to be similar to our line sensitivity, we assume that we will be able to make similar high fidelity continuum maps at 1.3mm. Assuming that the continuum is more compact (as it is in most ULIRGs) the continuum sensitivity is expected to be similar to our line sensitivities despite the ALMA OT's estimates.

We are mainly interested in detecting CO(2-1). The 1.875 GHz bandwidth will be used in dual polarization mode, with the CO(2-1) line placed in the lower sideband (LSB). We will also place the CS(5-4) line in the upper sideband (USB), in the event that this high-density line is strong enough to be detected in areas where the gas is more compact.

We require an angular resolution of 0.1? (corresponding to a physical scale of ~100 pc at z=0.044). This is sufficient to resolve individual large clouds, nuclear disks and structures around the nuclei for our two double nuclei systems.

In order to estimate the required sensitivities and integration times, we have used all existing CO mm-wave emission line and FIR/submm continuum data in the literature for each of our sources. Table 1 gives estimates of the total CO(2-1) emission line flux and the measured continuum fluxes for each target from the literature. We have made the conservative assumption that the total CO(2-1) emission is smoothly distributed within a nuclear region 2 arcsec in diameter. To estimate the required RMS sensitivity, we divided the estimated flux by the number of beams required to cover a 2 arcsec diameter with a pixel size of 0.1 arcsec (~300 beams) and assumed a channel width of 50 km/s. To reach a S/N of ~3 in the continuum, we will require an RMS sensitivity of ~400 uJy/synthesized beam and an integration time of 21 min on source. For more compact gas distributions, the S/N will of course be higher, but we would like to be able to detect extended faint structures such as high-velocity molecular winds, jets, plumes, etc., which may be present in the majority of our sources based on the most recent data from Herschel (Sturm et al. 2011). We will simultaneous get 1.3mm continuum which will be used to estimate dust masses. Given that continuum sensitivity expected to be similar to our line sensitivity, we assume that we will be able to make similar high fidelity continuum maps at 1.3mm. Assuming that the continuum is more compact (as it is in most ULIRGs) the continuum sensitivity is expected to be similar to our line sensitivities despite the ALMA OT's estimates.

We are mainly interested in detecting CO(2-1). The 1.875 GHz bandwidth will be used in dual polarization mode, with the CO(2-1) line placed in the lower sideband (LSB). We will also place the CS(5-4) line in the upper sideband (USB), in the event that this high-density line is strong enough to be detected in areas where the gas is more compact.

We require an angular resolution of 0.1 (corresponding to a physical scale of ~100 pc at z=0.058). This is sufficient to resolve individual large clouds, nuclear disks and structures around the nuclei for our two double nuclei systems.
Since the two nuclei are separated by ~7 arcsec, and given that ~90% of the total IR luminosity of this system comes from the northern nucleus, we will center our ALMA observation on the northern nucleus.

In order to estimate the required sensitivities and integration times, we have used all existing CO mm-wave emission line and FIR/submm continuum data in the literature for each of our sources. Table 1 gives estimates of the total CO(2-1) emission line flux and the measured continuum fluxes for each target from the literature. We have made the conservative assumption that the total CO(2-1) emission is smoothly distributed within a nuclear region 2 arcsec in diameter. To estimate the required RMS sensitivity, we divided the estimated flux by the number of beams required to cover a 2 arcsec diameter with a pixel size of 0.1 arcsec (~300 beams) and assumed a channel width of 50 km/s. To reach a S/N of ~3 in the continuum, we will require an RMS sensitivity of ~285 uJy/synthesized beam and an integration time of 54 min on source. For more compact gas distributions, the S/N will of course be higher, but we would like to be able to detect extended faint structures such as high-velocity molecular winds, jets, plumes, etc., which may be present in the majority of our sources based on the most recent data from Herschel (Sturm et al. 2011). We will simultaneous get 1.3mm continuum which will be used to estimate dust masses. Given that continuum sensitivity expected to be similar to our line sensitivity, we assume that we will be able to make similar high fidelity continuum maps at 1.3mm. Assuming that the continuum is more compact (as it is in most ULIRGs) the continuum sensitivity is expected to be similar to our line sensitivities despite the ALMA OT's estimates.

We are mainly interested in detecting CO(2-1). The 1.875 GHz bandwidth will be used in dual polarization mode, with the CO(2-1) line placed in the lower sideband (LSB). We will also place the CS(5-4) line in the upper sideband (USB), in the event that this high-density line is strong enough to be detected in areas where the gas is more compact.

We require an angular resolution of 0.1 (corresponding to a physical scale of ~100 pc at z=0.05). This is sufficient to resolve individual large clouds, nuclear disks and structures around the nuclei for our two double nuclei systems.

In order to estimate the required sensitivities and integration times, we have used all existing CO mm-wave emission line and FIR/submm continuum data in the literature for each of our sources. Table 1 gives estimates of the total CO(2-1) emission line flux and the measured continuum fluxes for each target from the literature. We have made the conservative assumption that the total CO(2-1) emission is smoothly distributed within a nuclear region 2 arcsec in diameter. To estimate the required RMS sensitivity, we divided the estimated flux by the number of beams required to cover a 2 arcsec diameter with a pixel size of 0.1 arcsec (~300 beams) and assumed a channel width of 50 km/s. To reach a S/N of ~3 in the continuum, we will require an RMS sensitivity of ~450 uJy/synthesized beam and an integration time of 19 min on source. For more compact gas distributions, the S/N will of course be higher, but we would like to be able to detect extended faint structures such as high-velocity molecular winds, jets, plumes, etc., which may be present in the majority of our sources based on the most recent data from Herschel (Sturm et al. 2011). We will simultaneous get 1.3mm continuum which will be used to estimate dust masses. Given that continuum sensitivity expected to be similar to our line sensitivity, we assume that we will be able to make similar high fidelity continuum maps at 1.3mm. Assuming that the continuum is more compact (as it is in most ULIRGs) the continuum sensitivity is expected to be similar to our line sensitivities despite the ALMA OT's estimates.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose use ALMA Band 6 to obtain the first detailed (0.1") maps of the nuclear molecular gas and continuum emission in a complete sample (4) of the nearest (z < 0.06) "warm" ULIRGs which appear to be transitioning into IR-excess, dust-enshrouded QSOs. All 4 of our targets have previously been detected in CO(2-1) emission with single dish telescopes, and 2 have been observed in CO(2-1) with interferometers at angular resolutions of ~4 arcsec. Both observations and new theoretical models show that the bulk (>70%) of the molecular gas has been funneled into the nuclear regions of these major-merger galaxy systems where putative super starbursts and AGN are responsible for powering their enormous infrared luminosity. Our proposed CO(2-1) observations will have a major impact on our ability to explore the starburst-AGN connection in these objects by allowing us to locate the sites of star formation, constrain the infrared luminosity of dust enshrouded AGN, and to measure the impact of feedback caused by dense molecular outflows, which now seem to be ubiquitous in these sources.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute for Astronomy, Hawaii at Manoa, University of
